prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3: 12CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe IRAS 13120-5453 in 12CO J=1-0 at a resolution of 0.2" (125 pc). One window is placed on the CN N=1-0 transition. The other two spectral windows will be used for continuum but we will not use the broadband setting in case we may find unexpected spectral lines.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875GHz) with a fine spectral resolution for each of the four spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (>=200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile and a fine spectral resolution will allow a good measurement of the line itself.
We place spectral windows near spectral lines that we may detect within the integration time to maximize the science output from the ALMA observations. Other windows will be used to measure the continuum; however, we will keep the fine spectral resolution in case unexpected spectral lines are detected.
One spectral window will be placed near the 12CO(1-0) line, another near the CN N=1-0 line and the other two spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum.

We require some of the best angular resolution in 12CO J=1-0 in order to resolve the spiral arms and the nuclei, assuming the nuclei are separated by more than 125 pc and are not along the same line of sight.
IRAS 131230-5453 is quite a compact source. Using the HST iamge, the extent of the galaxy is <2.5".The majority of CO emission in ULIRGs are observed to be concentrated in the central ~kiloparsc region; therefore, we estimate that the CO emission cannot be more than 2". The largest angular scale given in the OT for 12CO and 13CO(1-0) is the maximum that is allowed at this resolution. For the other science goals, the input value is 2". With a 0.2" beam, we will have ~10 beams across the galaxy allowing us to measure radial trends.

We assume a line ratio of CO 3-2/1-0 = 0.35 (3.2 in Jy units;), as was observed for Arp 220 (Downes & Solomon 1998), to estimate the peak flux of CO J=1-0. The peak flux is estimated to be 60 mJy (see technical justification for CO J=3-2 for estimate of CO J=3-2 flux). Assuming the spiral arms are 30 times weaker in emission than the peak, we require a sensitivity of 0.500 mJy for a 4 sigma detection in a 25 km/s channel width.
The channel width of 25 km/s is chosen to decrease the integration time on source. The line width of CO in ULIRGs are found to be very broad (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009); therefore, a broad channel width like 25 km/s will still give us a good line measurement.

See technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 science goal for bandwidth justification.
One spectral window is placed near 13CO J=1-0,another near CS J=2-1 and the other two will be used to measure the continuum. We still require a fine spectral resolution in case we detect unexpected spectral lines in the remaining two windows. This coverage will allow us to get the most science output from this band.
See technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

Assuming a line ratio of 12CO/13CO = 30 (not unreasonable for ULIRGs; Casoli et al. 1992), we estimate the peak flux of 13CO J=1-0 to be 2 mJy (see 12CO J=1-0 science goal technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 peak flux estimate). We require a sensivity of 0.38 mJy for a ~5 sigma detection per 30 km/s channel width.

See technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 science goal for bandwidth justification.
One spectral window is placed near 12CO J=1-0, another near 13CS J=5-4, another near CS J=5-4 and the remaining window will be used for continuum measurements.
See the technical justification for the 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

We assume a line ratio of CO 3-2/2-1 ~1 (2.25 in Jy units). Using the estimated CO J=3-2 peak (see the technical justification for CO J=3-2), we estimate the peak flux of CO J=2-1 to be 85 mJy within a 0.2" beam. Assuming the spiral arms are 30 times weaker in emission than the peak, we need a sensitivity of 0.7 mJy for 4 sigma detection at a 10 km/s channel width.

See the technical justfication for the 12CO J=1-0 science goal.
One spectral window is place near 13CO J=2-1, another near C18O J=2-1 and the remaining two spectral windows will be used for continuum measurements.
See the technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

Assuming a line ratio of 12CO/13CO = 30 (Casoli et al. 1992), we estimate the peak flux of 13CO J=2-1 to be 2.8 mJy (see 12CO(2-1) science goal technical justification for 12CO(2-1) flux estimate). We require a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy to detect the line at ~5 sigma level per 10 km/s channel width.

See technical justification for 12CO(1-0) science goal.
We place one spectral window near 12CO(3-2), another near HCO+(4-3) and the remaining two spectral windows will be used for continuum measurements.
See technical justification for 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

Assuming a CO 6-5/3-2 line ratio of 0.4 (0.1 in K units; e.g. Sliwa et al. 2013), the peak flux for CO 3-2 is 185 mJy (see 12CO J=6-5 science goal technical justification for peak flux estimate). We assume that the spiral arms features are 30 times weaker than the peak, we request a sensitivity of 1 mJy for a ~6sigma detection of the spiral arms per 20 km/s channel width.

See technical justification for 12CO(1-0) science goal.
We place one spectral window near 13CO(3-2), another near CS(7-6) and the remaining two spectral windows will be used for continuum measurements.
Note that the 13CO(3-2) is redshifted out of the absorption feature near 335GHz.
See technical justification for the 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

Assuming a line ratio of 12CO/13CO =30 (Casoli et al. 1992), we estimate the peak of 13CO J=3-2 to be 6.2 mJy (see 12CO(3-2) science goal technical justification for 12CO(3-2) flux estimate). We require a sensitivity of 1.2 mJy for a ~5 sigma detection level per 15 km/s.

See technical justificaton for 12CO(1-0) science goal.
We place one spectral window near 12CO(6-5), one near HCO+(7-6), one near HCN(7-6) and the last remaining window will be used for continuum measurements near the 12CO(6-5) line.
See the technical justification of the 12CO J=1-0 science goal.

We use the Herschel FTS CO J=6-5 flux of IRAS 13120-5453 to estimate the peak flux in a 0.3" beam. The total flux is measured to be 2315 Jy km/s. The source is roughly 2.5" in the HST image (a conservative number as it could be less than 2" for CO) across and we assume a line width of 200km/s (not unreasonable for ULIRGs; e.g. Iono et al. 2009); therefore, the peak flux within a 0.2" beam, assuming uniform emission, is 74 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 4 mJy for a ~19 sigma detection at a 30 km/s channel width.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ultra Luminous Infrared Galaxies (ULIRGs) are rare in the local universe making this class of objects difficult to study in great detail. IRAS 13120-5453 is the second nearest (D = 137 Mpc) ULIRG in the universe after Arp 220; however, IRAS 13120-5453 does not have any published ground-based CO observations. We propose to observe IRAS 13120-5453 in several 12CO and 13CO transitions for some of the first high-resolution (0.3" = 190 pc) CO observations of this ULIRG. When compared to Arp 220, IRAS 13120-5453 has a similar far-infrared luminosity but optical images show that IRS 13120-5453 is much more compact with ordered structure in the form of spiral arms. Using the proposed observations, we will study the distribution and physical conditions of the molecular gas, comparing it to other local ULIRGs such as Arp 220 and Mrk 231.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Code: 2013.1.00379.S Title: The Forgotten Local Ultra Luminous Infrared Galaxy PI: Kazimierz Sliwa This proposal is a revised resubmission of a Cycle 2 filler project that may not be completely observed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
